title: 103_s1178
content: The Act may be cited as the "Great Lakes Federal Effectiveness Act" and establishes the Great Lakes Research Council. The Great Lakes Research Council is established to advise and coordinate federal research activities for ecosystem protection of the Great Lakes. They are required to prepare an assessment of research activities needed within one year of the Act's enactment. The Great Lakes Research Council is mandated to prepare a document for interested parties, including an assessment of research activities required to meet the Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement goals, an inventory of existing Federal expertise and capabilities, and recommendations for both long-term and short-term actions. The Great Lakes Research Council is tasked with assessing research activities needed to meet Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement goals, inventorying Federal expertise, and making recommendations for long-term and short-term research priorities. They also participate in meetings on research issues, recommend data collection protocols, and assist in establishing research protocols for the Great Lakes ecosystem. The Great Lakes Research Council aims to enhance research and management protocols for the Great Lakes ecosystem, advise on establishing a comprehensive data base, and ensure timely dissemination of research findings to interested parties. The Great Lakes Research Council, established to enhance research and management protocols for the Great Lakes ecosystem, is comprised of research managers from various federal agencies with expertise in the field. Other non-Federal individuals may also serve on the Council. The Council membership determines instrumentality. Non-Federal individuals can serve as ex officio members. The Chairperson is elected for a two-year term. Compensation is provided for official duties. Interagency cooperation is required. Compensation for travel and transportation expenses is provided under section 5703 of title 5, United States Code. The head of each federal department or agency that is a member of the Council must cooperate to implement recommendations and provide necessary personnel, services, or facilities upon request. The Council members must cooperate to implement recommendations and provide necessary data or information upon request from the Chairperson. The Council will work with the International Joint Commission for coordination and funding. This Act will not affect the authority of any Federal agency for Great Lakes research. Sec. 105 of this Act defines the terms used, including "Council" as the Great Lakes Research Council, "Great Lakes" as specific lakes and connecting waters, and "Great Lakes research" as the application of scientific expertise. The Great Lakes Research Council defines "Great Lakes research" as the application of scientific expertise to study the physical, chemical, biological, and socioeconomic processes in the Great Lakes ecosystem. The Great Lakes Water Quality Agreement is a bilateral agreement between the United States and Canada signed in 1978 and amended in 1987.
